It’s our Constitutional duty to conduct oversight into this grave issue and to reach the conclusions of these investigations that will help us address this problem. We must make every effort to ensure our election process and our democracy are protected.

The Special Counsel’s statement today is yet another indicator Congress must continue with its investigations where he left off. There are already six committees currently conducting this work, including the House @WaysMeansCmte on which I sit.
These are both grave conclusions we must all take seriously.

Second, Mueller said that investigators concluded that Russia and Russian intelligence agencies made ‘multiple and systematic efforts’ to interfere with the 2016 election and that these attacks were successful.

First, Mueller said that if investigators had confidence that the President did not commit a crime, they would have explicitly said so. They could not conclude that the President did not commit a crime.
#Mueller THREAD: Today Special Counsel Mueller outlined two very specific conclusions from his report with which everyone should be concerned.

This is a big problem and we are going to work to fix it. I’m glad Democrats and Republicans are working together on a bipartisan solution. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wMLZv93Ezec …

We’ve all heard the stories – the $23,000 MRI, the $48,000 treatment for a bad rash. And we all know the heavy burden surprise medical bills can have on patients. In fact, one study found 20 percent of hospital visits that began in the emergency room resulted in a surprise bill.

That’s why today I stood with military families to support a bill the House will pass tomorrow to repeal this high tax, fix the problem and ensure these families can access the benefits they deserve. pic.twitter.com/9xvV3qmvzd

The Republican tax bill was rushed through with no input from experts, causing unintended consequences. One mistake meant Gold Star families and the children of fallen first responders were hit with an unfair tax burden on their survivor benefits.

CA growers and producers whose crops were damaged by wildfires and wildfire smoke deserve assistance and funding – a key provision I’ve fought to include in the final Supplemental Appropriations Act. This funding is critical for small, family growers who lost their crops. pic.twitter.com/7WpyTLMleO
Further, this President does not have authorization from Congress to go to war with Iran. Congress must continue to be briefed and consulted on any actions.
Diplomacy must always come first and we should be working to strengthen the Iran deal, not undermine it.
Just left a briefing by Secretary of State Pompeo, Acting Secretary of Defense Shanahan, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Dunford and other Intelligence Community officials on Iran.

65 years ago today, the Supreme Court ruled separate but equal facilities were inherently unequal. #BrownvBoard set the stage for desegregation across all sectors of our society—but there is still much work to be done. We must never stop fighting for racial equality and justice.

Today, by passing the #EqualityAct we simply say that #LGBTQ individuals deserve the same treatment under the law as anyone else – equal protection and freedom from discrimination. pic.twitter.com/TprQQMp1fP
Today we took a big step toward fuller equality. I was proud to vote for the #EqualityAct to prohibit discrimination against our #LGBTQ community.

Such discrimination is unacceptable and it’s exactly why the #EqualityAct has been widely endorsed by major organizations such as the California Association of Realtors, the AFL-CIO, the American Medical Association and the NAACP.

In more than 25 states, #LGBTQ individuals can be denied service at a restaurant, barred from buying a home or fired from their job because of who they are and without any recourse under the law. pic.twitter.com/V0lsXFWEy3
